title: 112_hr198
content: The "Veterans Dog Training Therapy Act" establishes a pilot program on dog training therapy within the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a pilot program to assess the effectiveness of using service dogs to address post-deployment mental health and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms in veterans with disabilities. The program will run for five years at three to five VA medical centers. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a five-year pilot program at selected VA medical centers to educate veterans with mental health conditions in service dog training. The program aims to address post-deployment mental health and post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms. The pilot program will include classroom and office space, storage for training equipment, access to other training areas, outdoor exercise space for dogs, and transportation for field trips. The program will be administered through Recreation Therapy. The pilot program under this section will be administered through the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs by a certified recreational therapist with administrative experience. A director of service dog training will oversee the training of dogs at selected medical centers for the program. The pilot program requires social services experience, teaching service dog training, working with veterans with PTSD, certified instructors at each site, selecting dogs from shelters, ensuring temperament and health clearances. The pilot program for service dogs requires dogs with adequate temperament and health clearances, teaching essential commands, living at the training site or a foster home, and involving hands-on training and grooming. The pilot program for service dogs includes lecture and hands-on training for veterans with disabilities to maximize therapeutic benefits and provide well-trained service dogs. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other post-deployment mental health conditions can participate if there are enough resources available. The pilot program allows veterans with disabilities to participate in service dog training, with a preference for those who have graduated from treatment programs. The Secretary will collect data on the program. The pilot program allows veterans with disabilities to participate in service dog training. The Secretary will collect data to determine the program's effectiveness in assisting veterans with reducing stigma, improving emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, and providing opportunities to help fellow veterans. The pilot program for veterans with disabilities involves service dog training to assist in reducing stigma, improving emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, providing opportunities to help fellow veterans, reintegrating into the community, reducing social isolation, building relationship skills, relaxing hyper-vigilance, improving sleep patterns, and decreasing the use of pain medication. The pilot program for veterans aims to decrease the use of pain medication. Reports to Congress will be submitted annually, detailing the number of participants, services provided, and the program's effects on veterans. The pilot program for veterans aims to assess the effects on symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder, family dynamics, insomnia, pain management, and overall well-being. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a "service dog training instructor" for veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder and other post-deployment issues. The instructor provides training in service dog handling.
